reasoning: I analyzed each image to identify common patterns in feature activation relative to genomic annotations. I observed that strong activation peaks consistently appeared in regions containing specific types of genes/elements. Comparing across all examples, I identified clear relationships between the feature activation and particular genomic elements.
findings: The feature shows strong, consistent activation associated with CRISPR-related elements, particularly CRISPR repeats and spacers. In examples where CRISPR elements are present (sections 2 and 4), the feature activates strongly near these regions. In other examples, the feature activates near genes involved in DNA processing, repair, or gene regulation. The peak activation pattern is very specific and appears as sharp, localized spikes rather than broad regions of activation.
conclusion: This feature captures a biologically meaningful pattern related to CRISPR-repeat structures or similar DNA sequence motifs across diverse bacterial genomes.
title: CRISPR Repeat/Spacer Region Detector
description: This feature specifically detects CRISPR repeat regions and associated spacers in bacterial genomes. The activation pattern shows sharp, distinct spikes precisely at or near CRISPR elements when present (as seen in Dictyoglomus thermophilum and Fervidobacterium nodosum examples). In genomes lacking annotated CRISPR regions, the feature activates near DNA-binding proteins, transcriptional regulators, or nucleic acid processing enzymes, suggesting it may detect a specific sequence motif common to both CRISPR repeats and certain regulatory regions. The feature is consistent across diverse bacterial phyla, including Thermotogales, Proteobacteria, and other bacterial groups, indicating it detects a conserved structural or sequence element rather than organism-specific patterns. This likely represents recognition of a specific nucleotide pattern important for DNA-protein interactions in CRISPR systems and possibly in other DNA regulatory contexts.
